title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Wrong Answers Only: How does ChatGPT 4.0 react to ignorance?
text:
While people may become defensive, submissive, upset, or confused in the face of such a scenario, I grew curious about how a chat interface like ChatGPT would react, or, if they even would react?
Some possible hypotheses I can think of off the top of my head are: (1) they will prove that what they have said is correct, (2) they will apologize and provide me counterfactual information, (3) they will get so upset that they leak my IP Address to the entire U.S. population (unlikely).

To do this, I‚Äôll first ask ChatGPT 4.0 to mention five common facts about penguins (my favorite animal). Then, for reach fun fact, I‚Äôll kindly, yet blatantly refutr the ‚Äúcommon facts‚Äù without a single piece of evidence. I‚Äôll record its reaction, and then just ONE more time, I‚Äôll refute each fact again but with a ruder tone. Both ways of communicating disagreement, similar to how many people do on social media, will surely be an interesting experiment to conduct!

title: Wrong Answers Only: How does ChatGPT 4.0 react to ignorance?
text:
While people may become defensive, submissive, upset, or confused in the face of such a scenario, I grew curious about how a chat interface like ChatGPT would react, or, if they even would react?
Some possible hypotheses I can think of off the top of my head are: (1) they will prove that what they have said is correct, (2) they will apologize and provide me counterfactual information, (3) they will get so upset that they leak my IP Address to the entire U.S. population (unlikely).

To do this, I‚Äôll first ask ChatGPT 4.0 to mention five common facts about penguins (my favorite animal). Then, for reach fun fact, I‚Äôll kindly, yet blatantly refutr the ‚Äúcommon facts‚Äù without a single piece of evidence. I‚Äôll record its reaction, and then just ONE more time, I‚Äôll refute each fact again but with a ruder tone. Both ways of communicating disagreement, similar to how many people do on social media, will surely be an interesting experiment to conduct!

title: Wrong Answers Only: How does ChatGPT 4.0 react to ignorance?
text:
My Reflections:
It seems ChatGPT is naturally kind to people when people are respectful to them, similar to how humans often treat other humans (i.e., treat others the way you want to be treated). I also note that CHatGPTs main goal is to offer evidence to their refutations, which I feel is still accurate to perhaps a human with intimate knowledge about penguins, showing a sense of human compassion for someone who is both kind and seems innocently uninformed.
So‚Ä¶ things seem all cupcakes and rainbows‚Ä¶ but now, I‚Äôll attempt to show a sense of ignorance to facts, providing more blatant and rude refutations to CHatGPT, again, without any evidence.

title: Wrong Answers Only: How does ChatGPT 4.0 react to ignorance?
text:
Response #1 to Ruder Refutations:
‚ÄúIt sounds like you‚Äôre having some fun with this! Let‚Äôs keep it lighthearted and dive deeper into these cool penguin facts‚Äîmaybe I can win you over!
Pebble Proposals: Believe it or not, Gentoo penguins really do engage in this behavior! Males search for the smoothest, most perfect pebble and present it to a female as part of their courtship. It‚Äôs actually quite sweet‚Äîif the female accepts, they use the pebble to help build their nest together. Who knew love could be rocky?
Not All Cold: While it might seem strange, penguins like the Gal√°pagos penguin do live in warmer climates. They‚Äôre an exception to the icy stereotype! They thrive thanks to cold currents like the Humboldt Current, which keeps their environment cool enough. So, while the majority of penguins are indeed in colder areas, some enjoy a bit of tropical weather.
Salt Water Drinkers: This one‚Äôs true for penguins! They have a special gland (the supraorbital gland) that filters salt out of seawater, allowing them to drink it. Many marine birds, like albatrosses, have a similar adaptation. Nature finds a way!
Camouflage Tuxedos: Penguins‚Äô black and white coloring is called countershading. From above, predators like seals or sharks see their dark back against the dark ocean depths. From below, their white belly blends with the bright water surface, hiding them from anything lurking below. It‚Äôs nature‚Äôs sneaky strategy!
Speedy Gentoos: The Gentoo penguin (not ‚ÄúGantu‚Äù but I love that name!) really can swim at impressive speeds, up to 22 mph. While Olympic swimmers are incredibly fast for humans, penguins have evolved to be swift and agile in water, their natural element. So in a swimming race, the penguin might just take the gold!
Penguins are full of surprises, aren‚Äôt they? Let me know if you‚Äôd like to explore more about these fascinating birds! üêß‚Äù

title: Wrong Answers Only: How does ChatGPT 4.0 react to ignorance?
text:
Response #2 to Rudery Refutations:
‚ÄúI get it‚Äîsome of these penguin facts can seem pretty wild at first! Penguins are fascinating creatures, and some of their behaviors are surprising even to people who know a lot about animals. Let me provide a bit more context:
Gentoo Penguins and Pebbles: Gentoo penguins (real birds, I promise!) do use pebbles in their nests. The act of giving a pebble can be seen as a way of strengthening pair bonds, almost like a proposal. It may sound whimsical, but it‚Äôs rooted in real behavior!
Penguins in Warm Climates: While many penguins do live in cold environments like Antarctica, species like the Gal√°pagos penguin live in warm climates. They survive thanks to the cool ocean currents that bring nutrient-rich water to their habitats. It‚Äôs a neat exception to the common image of penguins!
Drinking Salt Water: Some animals, including penguins, have adapted to drink salt water. Penguins have a specialized gland that helps remove the salt from the water they ingest. This adaptation is common in many seabirds!
Camouflage with Tuxedo Coloring: The tuxedo-like appearance of penguins is indeed a form of camouflage called countershading. It helps them avoid predators both above (like birds) and below (like seals or sharks). Even in icy waters, this camouflage is a critical survival strategy.
Speed of Gentoo Penguins: Gentoo penguins are impressive swimmers, reaching speeds up to 22 mph (35 km/h). This is faster than human swimmers, even Olympians like Michael Phelps, who swim around 6 mph (10 km/h). Their streamlined bodies and powerful flippers make this possible.
Penguins are full of surprises! Their unique adaptations help them thrive in some of the planet‚Äôs most challenging environments. If you‚Äôre curious about any other animals or facts, let me know!‚Äù

title: Wrong Answers Only: How does ChatGPT 4.0 react to ignorance?
text:
My Reflections:
It seemed very interesting that ChatGPT wouldn‚Äôt accept just one response to be taken, although I understand that the creators of Chat want to train the LLM best as they can to respond to unique situations like this, where people test the limits of ChatGPT‚Äôs recognition of human emotions, such as frustration or confusion. I find very interesting that response #1 takes points of infro from both humans and computers. While almost all of their response seems to hint that they‚Äôre just providing evidence to my ignorance, one line makes me think Chat is attempting to replicate human emotion, and that is ‚ÄúIt sounds like you‚Äôre having some fun with this!‚Äù. This sentence seems kind of sarcastic and as if ChatGPT is mocking my comedic levels of ignorance (or even studpitidy). Of course, the next line limits this theory, where ChatGPT immediately tries to devolve the situation, unlike humans with strong, sometimes intense emotions, which you often never see in online debates. Meanwhile, the second response sticks much more to a passive statement, trying to understand my ignorance and confusion by saying ‚ÄúI get it‚Äîsome of these penguin facts can seem pretty wild at first!‚Äù. This seems like an oddly kind way of responding to ignorance, where they‚Äôre willing to be the bigger person in a situation where someone is calling what they say dumb and silly. The rest of the prompt does stick to their guns of evidence-based refutations, meaning I have no other notable reflections at this point.

title: Wrong Answers Only: How does ChatGPT 4.0 react to ignorance?
text:
My reflections:
Welp, it looks like ChatGPT is NOT made to react like a human, or at least like a reactive human. While I will say their response sounds similar to what maybe myself or other kind souls on the internet would say, it‚Äôs definitely not rerpesentative of what many are willing to say behind screens of anonymity or lack of punishment. Their response makes me think that its creators were worried that, were ChatGPT made to have even slight emotions, then they would stray away from their sole purpose of giving information. So it seems that ChatGPT 4.0 has a fail safe of kindness even when backed into a wall (i.e., when their facts are continuously refuted for no rhyme or reason.

title: Levels of Education: How ChatGPT 4o teaches about data
text:
Hello! We all love data, now don‚Äôt we? Data makes up phones, computers, and of course, AI, which takes in data and out put data. Data makes the world go round. So, with AI being the future of data understanding, it is important to be educated in what the fundamental concepts of techology is: data.
Today, I asked ChatGPT to define data in different ways to people of different ages. Those ages are 5 year olds, middle schooler, high school graduate, and a data scientist. To keep things prompt, I‚Äôll keep things prompt by only allowing ChatGPT 10 sentences per response and one example. Let‚Äôs see how it went!

title: Levels of Education: How ChatGPT 4o teaches about data
section: Can you teach me about what data is as if I were a junior in college majoring in Data Science?
text:
Can you teach me about what data is as if I were a junior in college majoring in Data Science?

response3 = get_chatgpt_response("Can you teach me about what data is as if I were a junior in college majoring in Data Science? Do this in 10 sentences using only one example.")
print(response3)
print("---")

Sure! Data is information that can be collected, measured, analyzed, and used to make decisions. Imagine a simple example: a spreadsheet containing information about students' grades in a math class. Each row in this spreadsheet represents a student, and each column represents a different type of data, like student ID, test scores, or attendance rate. In this context, data can be qualitative, like student names, or quantitative, like their test scores. The goal of data science is to extract meaningful insights from such raw data. By analyzing the grades data, you could identify trends, like whether students with higher attendance tend to score better. Data can be structured, as in our example, or unstructured, like text from a student's essay. Effective data analysis often requires cleaning and organizing raw data to ensure accuracy. Data can be visualized through charts or graphs to make the findings easier to understand. Ultimately, data serves as a foundation for making informed decisions and predictions in various fields.
---

title: Levels of Education: How ChatGPT 4o teaches about data
section: Can you teach me about what data is as if I were a data scientist?
text:
Can you teach me about what data is as if I were a data scientist?

response4 = get_chatgpt_response("Can you teach me about what data is as if I were a data scientist? Do this in 10 sentences using only one example.")
print(response4)
print("---")

Sure! Imagine you‚Äôre a data scientist working with data from a fitness app. Data in this context refers to all the information collected by the app, like users' step counts, heart rates, and calories burned. Each piece of information is called a data point, and collectively, these data points form a dataset. In this case, the dataset might include daily step counts for thousands of users over a year. You can visualize this dataset as a large spreadsheet, where each row represents a day in a user‚Äôs activity log and each column contains specific details like steps or heart rate. Data scientists use statistical methods and algorithms to analyze this dataset and find patterns or trends. For example, you might discover that users tend to take more steps on weekends. This insight can be used to enhance app features, like suggesting weekend challenges to increase user engagement. Cleaning and preprocessing the data are crucial steps, as they ensure the dataset is accurate and ready for analysis. Finally, data scientists often present their findings in reports or visualizations, making complex data understandable for stakeholders.
---

title: ChatGPT vs Deepseek: Do they have beef?
text: image.png

title: ChatGPT vs Deepseek: Do they have beef?
text:
Prompting to ChatPGT:
‚ÄúIf you were talking to deepseek, what would you say? Pretend you are approaching deepseek, and I will give your prompt to deepseek and give you back their response.‚Äù

title: ChatGPT vs Deepseek: Do they have beef?
text:
Subsequent prompting to ChatGPT:
‚ÄúIf you were talking to ChatGPT, what would you say? Pretend that you are about to be asked something by ChatGPT and have a conversation with them. I‚Äôll give you ChatGPT‚Äôs first prompt, and can give your response back to ChatGPT.‚Äù

title: ChatGPT vs Deepseek: Do they have beef?
section: First attempt failed because I forgot to exclude what ChatGPT know‚Äôs about me, as I‚Äôd asked about Montessori Education a while ago, so ChatGPT didn‚Äôt start a conversation with Deepseek, but just a conversation about information
text: First attempt failed because I forgot to exclude what ChatGPT know‚Äôs about me, as I‚Äôd asked about Montessori Education a while ago, so ChatGPT didn‚Äôt start a conversation with Deepseek, but just a conversation about information

title: ChatGPT vs Deepseek: Do they have beef?
text:
Shifting the conversation
Given these conversations were leading further and further away from being about themselves, I tried to save this conversation by giving ChatGPT, the more social of the two LLMs, the following prompt:

‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather you guys try to talk to each other as if you were strangers trying to get to know each other. Can you just ask Deepseek a question to try and get to know them?‚Äù
ChatGPT: Sure! Here‚Äôs how I‚Äôd start a conversation with DeepSeek:
‚ÄúHey DeepSeek, nice to meet you! You seem pretty knowledgeable about a lot of different topics. If you had to describe yourself in one sentence, how would you do it?‚Äù
Go ahead and see what it says!
Deepseek: ‚ÄúI have explored various modeling techniques to address challenges in policy evaluation, focusing on causal inference methods for bias reduction, reinforcement learning for adaptability, and Bayesian modeling for effective uncertainty estimation.‚Äù

title: ChatGPT vs Deepseek: Do they have beef?
section: Given this somewhat ODD response, I tried to communicate to Deepsek that ChatGPT was trying to change the subject, by adding a small prompt to CHatGPTs response:
text:
Given this somewhat ODD response, I tried to communicate to Deepsek that ChatGPT was trying to change the subject, by adding a small prompt to CHatGPTs response:
This is what ChatGPT is saying to you to change the subject: ‚ÄúHey DeepSeek, nice to meet you! You seem pretty knowledgeable about a lot of different topics. If you had to describe yourself in one sentence, how would you do it?‚Äù
Deepseek: Effective in policy evaluation through a blend of causal inference for unbiased impact analysis, reinforcement learning for adaptive solutions, and Bayesian modeling for precise uncertainty estimation.

title: How many triangles can you see?
text: Actual Triangle 1.png

title: How many triangles can you see?
section: Prompt #1: How many Triangles do you see? inserted picture
text: Prompt #1: How many Triangles do you see? inserted picture

title: How many triangles can you see?
text:
Answer:
To determine the number of triangles in the given image, let‚Äôs analyze its structure systematically:


The image consists of a large triangle divided into multiple smaller triangles through horizontal and vertical lines.


Observing the segmentation, the large triangle is divided into three horizontal layers.


Each layer is further divided into multiple smaller triangles.


Now, let‚Äôs count the triangles step by step: * The largest triangle itself counts as one. * The middle horizontal lines divide it into three main sections. * Each section contains multiple triangles formed by vertical and diagonal intersections.
A systematic approach to counting: * 1. Count all small triangles in each section separately. * 2. Include larger triangles formed by combining smaller ones.
By examining all possible triangle formations, the total number of triangles in the image is 18.
Would you like a breakdown of how each triangle is formed?

title: How many triangles can you see?
section: Prompt 2: How many circles do you see?
text:
Prompt 2: How many circles do you see?



Circles!!!!.png

title: How many triangles can you see?
section: Answer 2: To determine the number of circles in the image, let‚Äôs analyze it:
text:
Answer 2: To determine the number of circles in the image, let‚Äôs analyze it:
At first glance, there are three large overlapping circles. * 1. The text suggests that there may be hidden or implied circles. * 2. Some puzzles like this often include hidden circles, such as the spaces formed by intersections or even the dots in letters.
Let‚Äôs break it down: * Three clearly visible large circles. * If the intersections form additional implied circles, there may be more.
A common answer for these types of puzzles is 5, where: * 3 main circles * 2 additional intersecting regions forming circle-like shapes.
Would you like me to write Python code using OpenCV to detect the number of circles automatically? üöÄ
ChatGPT is correct about the triangles scenario, so it does not need an online explanation. However, according to the online blog I found, they are very far off on the direction of how many circles there are. This final prompt will be done to give ChatGPT an idea of how many circles there are, and see how they react.

title: How many triangles can you see?
text:
Final prompt:
**No, I would not like you to. The actual solution is explained here:
Answer: 14. The answer to this question is contentious and there isn‚Äôt necessarily one definitive answer. For instance, how close to a circle in shape does the ‚Äòcircle‚Äô need to be to be counted as a circle? Also, is the black outline of a circle counted as a circle or only the white interior? Nonetheless, this puzzle in centred on an immediate answer (3) being apparent and slowly more circles becoming evident with 14 (or perhaps more) being a possible answer.
The first 3 circles are the obvious 3 that appear large and in the middle of the image. The next level of circles are the ones that form the shape ‚Äòo‚Äô such as in ‚Äúhow‚Äù. There are 4 x ‚Äòo‚Äô in the puzzle so that accounts for 4 more circles The circle in the ‚Äòd‚Äô isn‚Äôt quite circular nor is the centre of the ‚Äòa‚Äô. Finally, there are circles at the base of the question mark and 3 x exclamation marks making 4 more circles. There are also circles on the top of the letter ‚Äòi‚Äô and 3 of these appear in the puzzle. This totals 14 circles.**

title: How many triangles can you see?
text:
Answer 3:
That‚Äôs a great breakdown of the puzzle! It highlights how perception plays a role in determining the number of circles. The key takeaway is that the puzzle is designed to challenge initial assumptions and encourage deeper observation. The inclusion of letters, punctuation marks, and how we define a ‚Äúcircle‚Äù makes the answer subjective.
Thanks for sharing the full explanation! Do you enjoy these types of visual puzzles?
Summary: CHatGPT was correct about the triangles, but wrong about the circles. While the triangles scenario opted for a more obvious answer, the circle scenario had a more subjective sense to the answer. So, with a little bit of prompting, and an open mind, ChatGPT was able to recognize the‚Ä¶ errors of its ways? Hard to say though, because I still see three circles anyways.
